title: 1940 Homestead Grays season
text:
The 1940 Homestead Grays baseball team competed in the <a href="Negro%20National%20League%20%281933%E2%80%931948%29">Negro National League</a> during the <a href="1940%20in%20baseball">1940 baseball season</a>. The Grays compiled a 34–19 () record and won the <a href="List%20of%20Negro%20league%20baseball%20champions">Negro National League championship</a>. The team played its home games at <a href="Griffith%20Stadium">Griffith Stadium</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>
<a href="Vic%20Harris%20%28outfielder%29">Vic Harris</a> was the team's manager and left fielder.
First baseman <a href="Buck%20Leonard">Buck Leonard</a> compiled a .369 batting average, .475 <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a>, and .619 <a href="slugging%20percentage">slugging percentage</a> with eight home runs and 48 RBIs in 49 games. Leonard was later admitted to the <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Baseball Hall of Fame</a>.
Third baseman <a href="Howard%20Easterling">Howard Easterling</a> and center fielder <a href="Jerry%20Benjamin">Jerry Benjamin</a> also had strong seasons at the plate with batting averages of .344 and .333, respectively. 
<a href="Ray%20Brown%20%28Negro%20leagues%20pitcher%29">Ray Brown</a> led the pitching staff with a 16–2 win-loss record with a 1.88 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> (ERA) and 67 strikeouts. Brown was also inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
<a href="Edsall%20Walker">Edsall Walker</a> was the team's No. 2 pitcher. He compiled an 11–4 record with a 3.13 ERA and 69 strikeouts.
